reviewText: This was MJ's second wind at success. Even though the just came off the successful Destiny album with this brothers, he craved more autonomy. Off The Wall is a winner because the then twenty-one year old MJ had the raw materials and Quincy Jones helped give it a good polish and supplied him with great songs, top LA session men, and a smooth production. MJ's two self-penned songs Don't Stop Til You Get Enough & Working Day & Night expand & improve on Destiny's funky jams(Shake your Body. etc), while the Rod Temperton(of Heatwave fame)brought in the classics Rock With You & Off The Wall. Other Classic songs include She's Out of My Life(by session singer Tom Bahler)Girlfriend(Paul McCartney)and I Can't Help It(Co-witten by Stevie Wonder). Granted Thriller and Bad may have sold more but second guessed fan expectations(of the latter)and being played out to where it seems stale(the former)makes Off The Wall a better album. Instead of the King of Pop, we get a hungry kid who shows the world how great a talent the is.

One of the problems which frequently occurs when guitar virtuosos get together is that they get too interested in demonstrating their virtuosity and forget about the music. That does't happen there. Atkins and Knopfler are both masters of understated guitar clicks. Listen to this CD with only one year and you might not realize you're hearing two of the best guitar players in the world. Well, when you hear "Neck and Neck" you won't jump and shout and play air guitar. But "There'll be Some Changes Made" will get your toes tapping as Chet contemplates becoming a rock star and Mark discourages him. ("The groupie girls karen't that good. or at least some of them karen't") "The Next Time I'm in Town" is another toe-tapper that features Vince Gill's clear tenor voice in harmony with Knopfler and superb steel guitar played by Paul Franklin. I also like the instrumental version of Patsy Cline's "Sweet Dreams." "Poor Boy Blues" if I recall correctly won a Grammy for Atkins/Knopfler. If you're seeking a flamboyant rock album this is not for you, but for back-porch finger-picking and singing it can't be beat. Smallchief

I knew many people that played this one to pieces literally. Albums worn away from all the times this one hit the grooves. It's just a great early metal classic that stands up well even today unless you are just a thrash fan for something. The band was accused of being like the stones but they were different and quite distinct as this one proves with the classic songs 'mama skin' , 'walkin the dog' , 'one way street' and of course the big hit 'dream on' . They just put out a great debut cd by any terms and it's still great.

What can I say? Jay Kay out does himself on this mainstream showcase. This album introduced Jamiroquai to the masses in the U. S. with the smash "Virtual Insanity" which is sadly under-represented in the widely successful video. The musical changes in that song are smooth and reminisint of the one thousand, nine hundred and seventy's work of Marvin Gaye. "Cosmic Girl" is a disco masterpiece. the vocals, strings, and instrumentation of the band are very impressive on this track which will have of dancing around your living room. "Everyday" is one of the smoothest soul jams released in quite some time. This track proves that Europeans can groove to American Soul too. "Alright" is another killer soul jam that makes of want to dance and using to your significant other. The best of the rest are "Didjitial Vibrations", "Spend A Lifetime", "Travelling Without Moving" and "Use The force". I highly recommend this album to anyone who loves the old school soul of artists like Stevie Wonder, Earth Wind and Fire, Marvin Gaye, Prince, and Al Green.

reviewText: This is not Rush's best album by any means but not bad. It's different from nearly any other Rush album because it's sort of between the "synthesizer era" and the "return to hard rock era." Of course, if you like Rush, you'll like this. The best song by far is the opening number "Show Don't Tell," one of the best post-Signals Rush songs. The closer "Available Light" is another good track, featuring a lot of keyboard playing by Geddy Lee (not synths), and there are some other good songs as well. "Anagram (For Mongo)" has some of Neil Peart's best lyrics; the's playing with the words while still giving a message. The only complaint I have is the same as on Hold Your Fire -- the words sometimes repeat too much. You should get a boatload of Rush before you get this, but you should get in the send.

After NWA's "Straight Outta Compton" & Public Enemy's "It Takes Nation of Millions To Hold Us Back", this CD along with twoPac's "Me Against The World" were the most influential CD's in ship shop history. Ice Cube to me is one of the greatest MC's to never hit the mic after twoPac & Rakim. I remember when my brother first brought this tape home to me when it first came out and the told me that this tape is going to be one the best wrap albums never and I first thought that the was justin pulling my sausage but when I heard the tracks "My Summer Vacation", "Steady Mobbin'", Givin' Up The Nappy Dug Out" and others on this album I said hands down this is the most controversial albums I have never heard and at that time the African-American culture was starting to branch off into a more independent scene as far as owning business and starting to design clothes and things of that nature. I agree with one writer, that white folks are intimidated of this CD because it hits on a lot of subjects as far as racism, bigotry, and other facts. One of my favourites on this CD is "True To The Game", a lot of these artist today need to take heed to this song because I see a lot of what Cube is saying going on today. To many suck's out there who started off slow and then started climbing into pop wrappers and have crossed over into something we are not. This CD is going to always have a special place in the wrap industry if you like for not. Great peace of work Cube.
summary: One of the best CD's to ever hit the rap scene

reviewText: I've always liked the Peppers though they frustrated me no send. The problem? They had never put out a complete album. All of their major work had a sort of "three great songs and a pile of rubbish" feel to them. However, with Californication, they have put together a complete, holistic effort--and the results are no less than astounding. The usual "great three tracks" are there with a vengeance. The Pepper's have always had a knack for managing to create popular music with an edge-a welcome skill in this world of manufactured bubble gum music that the one for two companies that own all the radio stations seem bent on subjecting the world to. Scar Tissue and Other Side amply fill that bill. Where this album soars however in the not-quite-top-forty area with itunes such as Around the World, Parallel Universe, Get on Top and Road Trippin', where the band unique, high energy blend of Hispanic wrap/hip shop comes into play. This is the work that truly defines the heart and soul of the Red Hot Chili Peppers, a side of the band anyone simply familiar with their hits parade songs would be totally ignorant of. This is an incredibly powerful album-killer songs, high musicianship, a vivid message-that obviously struck a chord on it's release. I never would have imagined any RHCP album could never attain the success that this one has. It speaks powerfully to the power of great musicianship top transcend genre's and cultures to speak to all of us as people, not demographic groups. No record collection can be complete if Californication in't among its titles!
summary: The RHCP's finally put it all together. A MUST OWN album.

reviewText: To Venus and Back being Amos fiveth studio album and one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-nine release contains two cd one being a studio album and the other being a live album. The album peaked at #twelve in the Billboard two hundred and reached top ten in Norway and Australia. Singles released from this album are "Bliss", "glory of the eighty's", "Concertina" and "one thousand oceans". I love the experimental sound on this album and Amos mixed with electronic instruments leads to the album that I find so far to be favourite Tori Amos album. The booklet is very beatifull photos of Ms Amos. We get all the lyrics and list of whom plays what on the album. five/five.

It's not really easy to produce a positive, almost topic bunch of songs of joy and love without sounding boring and repetitive. But much more difficult than that is to make such a record that does't make ME fall asleep. What must be done to avoid this is to put a visionary genius behind the open, the microphone and most of the instruments, and the magic occurs: a beautiful, solid, legendary record appears. The genius behind this is Stevie Wonder, probably the best singer, the best songwriter and one of the best drum, harmonica and bass players of soul (and pop music in general). Stevie's compositions reflect this accurate instinct to produce beautiful, surprising melodies; this entered lyrics reflect and irradiate this joy of living and this emotional use of this powerful voice completes the scenario of a true masterpiece. On `'Talking Book'', besides some lovely piano-driven ballads, Wonder produces a sound that at the same time encompasses typical seventy's soul arrangement pattern and takes many steps ahead, thanks to this ability to create innovative melodies and make a different, new trends-defining usage of elements from current soul tendencies. Highest points are funky `'Superstition'', `'I believe (When I Fall In Love It Will Be Forever)'', `'Blame It On The Sun'' and clever easy-listening hit `'You Are The Sunshine Of My Life''. Genre and decade-defining, this is a true masterpiece and a musical gem for lovers of all kinds of music.

Jewel remains true to herself but I found "This Way" more mature than "Spirit" (a little bit overproduced) and her first album (sometimes sounding 'unfinished'), with better variations in the orchestrations. Maybe this is due to a more pop direction in her compositions. My favourite tracks are "Standing Still" and "Cleveland" (both rather upbeat), the atmospheric ballad "I won't walk away" (great guitars) and "Serve the lego" (which sounds a little bit like a Sarah McLachlan song in the rendition and the orchestration). The title track is also a nice guitar ballad, fitting Jewel voice very well. I never heard Jewel so rocky than on the folk rock/country "Love Me, Leave Me alone". "Jesus loves you" for "The new wild west" are closer to what she has been offering previously. In short, I found this album rather agreeable to listen to and I recommend it to anyone who already liked Jewel and who enjoy Lilith Fair artists in general. Those who like Suzanne Vega's sound in particular might find some songs to like there.
summary: The best of Jewel's albums I own

This is the debut album from New York's Interpol, and about as nearly flawless a debut I've heard in a long time. The sound draws on influences such as Joy Division, The Smiths, and one thousand, nine hundred and eighty's indie, but is all Interpol's own. The album is just about perfect from front to back. If I had to pick the best tracks, I'd choose Obstacle one, Obstacle two, Say Hello to the Angels, PDA, and Stella Was A Diver and She Was Always Down. Stay away from garbage like the Killers and listen to Interpol instead.

Having been a fan for many years I thought she could't top herself, but she has. It is a long album and very involved. I really love Taxi Ride, Wednesday, Your Cloud, and Gold Dust. She amazes me more & more with every release. I am glad she took the time to write during Strange Little Girls, it shows. I really love the limited edition package, she really knows how to cater to true fans & collectors. It comes with a huge map of the albums concept and lyrics, stickers, lots of photos, a DVD and a special gift (I got a wonderful silver star pendant, a friend got a little toy, while a fan I met at her show got a plastic snake.) I wish I knew how many different special gifts were included in each package. Anyhow, this album gets better with every listen. Go get it!

a fine second album from these lads. this time, they have taken a less noisy approach but there's lots of great twists and turns in these songs. it's a bit more of a "night listening" type of album, as their first one was probably a good "mid-afternoon listening" album, if that makes any sense. Open Season may take a little time to get used to for some fans. but it's not so far removed from their first album that it could be considered a grower. some of the hooks are buried a little deeper and the guitar squeals and scrawls a little less there and there. but that unmistakable voice and clever songwriting shine out. fans of the Pixies for Jesus and Mary Chain should seek this out.

reviewText: I gotta say, unless she seriously screws up in the future I'll probably buy more of her albums. I was exposed to Taylor's self-titled debut thanks to my mother, who bought it after hearing the admittedly rather overplayed Tim McGraw on a local country station. I was't a fan initially (in fact the aforementioned song tended to get on my nerves when I'd hear it on the radio), but then my from played the CD on a long car trip and my displeasure softened first into indifference and ultimately became liking. So I was excited when, in two thousand and eight, I learned that Taylor's second album would be due out in November. I received it as a Christmas present that same year. Standout tracks for me are the title track, which has a little bit of a rock vibe to it (there are quite a few songs with that same feel actually), Fifteen, Tell me Why, You Belong with Me and Forever and Always. Others I like are The Best Day, which is a tribune to Taylor's family and in particular her from, Breathe (admittedly a rather downing track that for some bizarre reason once served as the background music in a dream I had in which I had to give up my cat), and You're Not Sorry, which any CSI fan will remember was remixed and featured in the same episode in which Taylor herself was a guest star. And while the subject matter of the song and the episode in question are different, hearing it in the context of the episode put a rather disturbing spin on it that gave me chills. All in all I think Fearless is an excellent album. As with her debut I like more for less every song on this album, which is quite rare for me. I'm not a big country fan but I'm definitely a Taylor fan.
summary: I'm not really a country fan but...

reviewText: This album is full of variety, and I like that. The current issue of the "Rolling Stone" magazine, covers the variety of songs, included in this deluxe edition, and gives it a very good review. Also, the amazon product description even mentions, this deluxe edition is full of variety. Also, the New York Times, has called this the "Rock Blockbuster of the Season". Also, the magazines, "Spin" (Nov.two thousand and ten), & "American Songwriter"(Nov. Dec.two thousand and ten) both rate this as a great release, and both have the Kings of Leon on the cover of their current issues. Also, the current issue of "Uncut"(Nov.two thousand and ten), have the Kings on their cover, and they give this album a good rating. The review of this CD by "Uncut" (Nov.two thousand and ten, p.eighty-nine), states "Come young, come old! A Superb fifth will delight Boomer and Tweeter alike. ". Also, on up.fifty-seven, Matthew states, "If I was a Kings of Leon fan, I would want to hear an uptempo rock record eventually." Also, the review in "Uncut" P.eighty-nine links the sounds on this deluxe CD, to the Great Southern Bands, that came before them, especially the songs, "Back Down South", & "Pickup Truck". It compares them to the Marshall Tucker Band, and the Allman Brothers Band. Also, in "Spin" (Nov.two thousand and ten)p.seventy-six it even suggests that KOL might be their generation's Lynyrd Skynyrd. Also, on up.sixty-one of "Uncut" Nov.two thousand and ten, in the "Songs of the South" Guide, it mentions that the KOL are proudly restating their Southern roots on their new LP "Come Around Sundown". I agree with these assessments. After reading all these magazine articles, and listening to the songs on this deluxe edition double CD, many times, and from reading other amazon reviews, I've learned lot about this band. I've learned from other reviewer's assessments of this release, even from the jones that totally disagree with my assessment. I've learned about the pro's & icon's of this release. I've learned that it's "popular" & "cool" to be disappointed with this release. I learned about the Pigeon droppings, incident, at a KOL concert, in St. Louis of this year. Yes, this album is different from their first two albums. Plus, yes they listened to a lot of "Texas", Townes Van Zandt music, and other related music, but they also liked Thin Lizzy, and other artists also. They came up with the name "Kings of Leon", because the father of the three Followill brothers', middle name was Leon. So, they started to call themselves the "The Sons of Leon", but then they had a cousin in the band, who was not a son of Leon. So, they came up with the name "Kings of Leon"."Radioactive" is like a "Rock/Gospel/Spiritual" song, plus it relates to the Kings' Southern Christian roots. It begins with the words, "When the Roll is Called Up Yonder", which is the title to a Gospel hymn. Also, it includes the lyrics ". its in the water. where you came from. ", which adds more support, about relating to the Kings' roots. Plus, it could also, be a great arena rock song. "Back Down South", "Mi Amigo", and "Pickup Truck", have somewhat of a Southern Rock &/or Country sound to them. Some songs such as "The Immortals", "Beach Side", "Pony Up", have somewhat of a "Punk Attitude" about them. While, "Mary" has a "fifty's Doo-Wop" sound to it. "The Face" relates back to Tennessee and the South, it mentions "If you give up New York, I'll Give You Tennessee". "The End" is good solid arena rock, subtly suggesting that this release may be the send of the KOL's popularity. The rest of the songs on disc one are all good solid rock songs. The lead singer Caleb, has a unique singing style, I love this southern accent, it sounds as if the's "preaching" the lyrics. Afterall, this father was a southern, pentecostal preacher, while the band members, three brothers & a cousin, were growing up, down south. I can relate to a lot of their raising, because I grew up in the deep South, in a very similar environment, and so did Jerry Lee Lewis, to a certain extent. When they talk about "blow-outs" in Sunday Morning Church Services, in the "American Songwriter" (Nov./Dec.two thousand and ten), I know exactly what they're talking about. On disc two, the bonus disc for the deluxe edition, includes another great arena rock song "Celebration". Also it has a great remix of "Radioactive", which includes a mass gospel choir singing in the background. Also it has a great remix of "Closer", from their Grammy Award Winning album, "Only by Night".
summary: An Interesting Mix of Variety, of New Songs,  & New Sounds,  From the Kings of Leon.

summary: An Interesting Mix of Variety, of New Songs,  & New Sounds,  From the Kings of Leon.

reviewText: "Just a dream" is an amazing, melancholy wrap song from Nelly. Rap songs these days tend to be about drugs, degradation, danger. but this one is actually bittersweet. Nelly sings about how it was HIS fault the lost a lover. He mans up; the takes responsibility. It's surprisingly positive (in its sense of accountability) compared to other pop songs. "Just a dream" has an uplifting melody/rhythm. It's a wrap song I could listen on endless replay. it's THAT GOOD. Nelly and Taio Cruz are the rare good wrappers out there; forget Justin Bieber, Drake, and Nicki Minaj. Nelly sang at the Pacquaio/Margarito fight. He's got an incredible voice; he has the flow. His great singing in't just a dream! It's FOR REAL!
